property.name: mediadisplayblurb
property.value: U.S. service member speaking with an Afghan local

note.text: The terms "high-context" and "low-context" compare how people within a society generally communicate. In this instance, context refers to the circumstances of an interaction and the response of participants based on their cultural conditioning. "High" and "low" have to do with the degree of directness in communication.

In high-context communications, much of the information is implied, as opposed to being explicit. The receiver of a message needs to have an understanding of the cultural context to fully understand the communication. This type of communication, where much of the message is not explicitly stated, is common in Asian, African, and Arab countries.

In contrast, low-context communications are more explicit and very little information is left to inference. This means that the receiver of a message is likely to understand all the information even if they know little of the cultural context. This type of communication, where the message is explicitly stated, is more common in the U.S., as well as England, Germany, and Australia.

property.name: mediacaption
property.value: U.S. Air Force photo by Master Sgt. William Greer

note.text: In general, someone coming from a low-context communication environment may have difficulty understanding what is going on in a high-context communication environment. They may not understand the unstated, yet implied meaning of communication and may miss information that is not explicitly communicated.
